replies.msg: XLE

Bloomberg) -- Favorable Covid-19 vaccine news means the long winter for value investing could be ending. In its Nov. 16 issue, Barron’s argues that value stocks -- which trade cheaply compared to their present cash-flow value -- usually perform better than growth stocks in an economic recovery.
JPMorgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS), both operating profitably during the pandemic, are among leading value stocks, Barron’s says. Berkshire Hathaway (BRK/A)’s class A shares also look cheap. The conglomerate will likely benefit from a reopening because of its industrial and railroad holdings.
Drug and energy stocks are inexpensive. Pfizer (PFE), whose vaccine development sparked a markets rally, only rose modestly itself. Despite depressed oil prices, U.S. production has fallen about 15% this year, a hopeful sign for the industry.
Small-cap stocks are more economically sensitive than large-cap issuers. Overseas index funds that have high exposure to financials and industrials can also benefit disproportionately from an economic recovery. Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) and Lukoil (LUKOY), Russia’s largest oil company, are appealing, says Barron’s.
Gold remains a good hedge against inflation amid government stimulus.
Other highlights from this week’s magazine:
Target (TGT) is still undervalued and cheaper than peers, despite having risen 27% so far this year, Barron’s says. The company deepened its strategy of being a one-stop-shop, adding Ulta Beauty (ULTA) in stores through a recent partnership. Foot traffic never dropped more than 2% from 2019 levels all summer, Placer.ai data show.
Memory chip maker Micron Technology (MU) could see its stock double from here, Barron’s writes. It’s a cheap play on 5G and electric vehicles, as their demand for chips is set to rise. Micron closed Friday at $57.93.
Intel (INTC), down 25% so far this year, can recover. The company still dominates in the computer processing units market and outsourcing could boost the stock. It has also indicated a willingness to try new things. Intel isn’t the next General Electric, Barron’s writes.

Overseas index funds that have high exposure to financials and industrials can also benefit disproportionately from an economic recovery. Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) and Lukoil (LUKOY), Russia’s largest oil company, are appealing, says Barron’s.
Gold remains a good hedge against inflation amid government stimulus.
Other highlights from this week’s magazine:
Target (TGT) is still undervalued and cheaper than peers, despite having risen 27% so far this year, Barron’s says. The company deepened its strategy of being a one-stop-shop, adding Ulta Beauty (ULTA) in stores through a recent partnership. Foot traffic never dropped more than 2% from 2019 levels all summer, Placer.ai data show.
Memory chip maker Micron Technology (MU) could see its stock double from here, Barron’s writes. It’s a cheap play on 5G and electric vehicles, as their demand for chips is set to rise. Micron closed Friday at $57.93.
Intel (INTC), down 25% so far this year, can recover. The company still dominates in the computer processing units market and outsourcing could boost the stock. It has also indicated a willingness to try new things. Intel isn’t the next General Electric, Barron’s writes.

標普500根據近年的創新高次數統計

* 2019: 19次

* 2018: 18次

* 2017: 高達62次

自從1928年以來，大約有5%的交易日會創新高，也就是平均20天就有一天突破新高。
換句話說，有95%的時間，你會看財經新聞這樣寫著「今天大盤從歷史新高下跌，天要黑了？」

這不代表市場永遠不會大崩跌。

但如果你想等低點才進場，你很有可能，眼睜睜看著指數一直漲上去，錢卻一直放銀行…浪費時間成本及長期複利的威力。
